meanings: The ability to do something means you have the skill or talent to do it well, like riding a bike or drawing a picture.
examples: My sister has the ability to draw amazing pictures of animals.
During gym class, I discovered my ability to run really fast.
With practice, I improved my ability to play the piano beautifully.
My dog has the ability to learn new tricks quickly and easily.
In science class, we learned about the ability of plants to grow in sunlight.

meanings: Next to each other or side by side, like when you walk with a friend and stay close together.
examples: The two dogs ran abreast down the path, wagging their tails happily.
In the race, we ran abreast, trying to keep up with each other.
At the picnic, we sat abreast on the blanket, sharing our snacks.
The kids lined up abreast for the school picture, all smiling wide.
During the hike, we walked abreast so we could chat easily.

meanings: Happening suddenly and without warning, like when a loud noise surprises you.
examples: The teacher made an abrupt change to our schedule, and we had art class instead of math.
When the storm came, the weather turned abrupt, and we had to go inside quickly.
I was surprised by the abrupt ending of the movie; I wanted to see what happened next!
My dog made an abrupt jump when he saw a squirrel run by the window.
The basketball game took an abrupt turn when our team scored three points in a row!

meanings: To achieve means to successfully do something you wanted to do, like finishing a homework assignment or scoring a goal in a game.
examples: I worked hard to study for my test, and I was happy to achieve a good grade.
When we practiced every day, our team was able to achieve a trophy in the soccer tournament.
I set a goal to read five books this month, and I’m excited to achieve it!
With teamwork, we can achieve our project and make it the best in the class.
My sister practiced her dance moves so she could achieve her dream of performing on stage.

meanings: Being busy and doing things, like playing sports, running around, or helping out.
examples: I like to stay active by riding my bike and playing outside with my friends.
My dog is very active; he loves to run and chase after the ball in the park.
In gym class, we do active games like tag and relay races to stay healthy and have fun.
Being active during the day helps me sleep better at night and feel happy.
My sister is active in dance class, where she learns new moves and performs for our family.

meanings: To address someone means to talk to them or to write their name and where they live on a letter or package so it can reach them.
examples: I wrote my friend's address on the envelope so the letter would reach her.
The teacher asked us to address our letters to the principal for the school project.
When I send a birthday card, I always write my grandma's address carefully.
At the soccer game, the coach will address the team before we start playing.
I need to remember my new address because we moved to a different house.

meanings: An advantage is something that helps you do better or makes a situation easier. For example, having a friend to help you with homework is an advantage because it makes learning more fun!
examples: Having a good night's sleep gives you an advantage in school the next day.
In soccer, being faster than the other players can be a big advantage during the game.
If you practice your reading, you will have an advantage when taking tests.
Using a map can give you an advantage when exploring new places in nature.
Helping your friend with homework can be an advantage for both of you in learning.

meanings: To change how someone feels or acts; for example, if your smile makes a friend happy, your smile affects them.
examples: The weather can affect how we play outside during recess.
If I study hard, it will affect my grade on the test.
My smile can affect how my friend feels when she's sad.
Eating healthy foods can affect how strong and energetic I feel.
When I practice my soccer skills, it can affect how well I play in the game.

meanings: To have enough money to buy something or do something you want. For example, if you can buy a toy because you saved up your allowance, you can afford it.
examples: I want to buy a new video game, but I need to save money to afford it.
My parents said we can’t afford to go to the amusement park this year.
I hope I can afford a new bicycle for my birthday.
If I save my allowance, I can afford to buy a special treat for my friends.
My mom said we can afford to adopt a puppy if we all help take care of it.

meanings: To ail means to feel sick or not well. It’s when your body or mind is having a hard time, like when you have a cold or feel sad.
examples: My little brother often ails from a cold when the weather gets chilly.
When I feel sad, I try to talk to my mom about what ails me.
The dog looked like it ailed after running too fast in the park.
Sometimes, my friend ails from headaches when she doesn’t drink enough water.
We all felt a bit of aail after playing outside in the hot sun for too long.

meanings: To change something a little bit, like when you color a drawing differently or switch around your toys.
examples: I can alter my drawing by adding more colors to make it look brighter.
We decided to alter our game rules to make it more fun for everyone.
My mom will alter my dress so it fits me better for the party.
The teacher asked us to alter our stories by adding a surprise ending.
We can alter our plans if it rains and play inside instead.

meanings: Amiable means being friendly and kind, like someone who always smiles and makes others feel happy.
examples: My amiable teacher always greets us with a smile when we enter the classroom.
The amiable dog wagged its tail and happily licked my hand when I visited the pet shelter.
At the birthday party, everyone enjoyed the amiable games that made us laugh and have fun together.
My amiable neighbor often helps me with my homework and brings cookies when I visit.
During the soccer game, our amiable coach cheered for us and made sure we had a great time.

meanings: Very old; something that has been around for a long time, like dinosaurs or ancient buildings.
examples: The ancient tree in our park is over a hundred years old and has very thick branches.
In history class, we learned about ancient Egypt and how they built the pyramids.
My grandfather told me stories about ancient times when he was a boy, and life was different.
The ancient rock formations at the beach are millions of years old and look really cool.
I found an ancient coin in my dad's collection that was used a long time ago.

meanings: Happening once every year, like a birthday party or a school event that takes place every year.
examples: Our school has an annual talent show where students can sing, dance, or perform magic tricks.
Every summer, my family goes to the annual fair with rides, games, and delicious cotton candy.
My soccer team has an annual picnic at the end of the season to celebrate our hard work.
We look forward to our annual camping trip where we roast marshmallows and tell stories by the fire.
The library hosts an annual reading contest to see who can read the most books in a month.

meanings: To feel very surprised and upset because something is really bad or shocking.
examples: I was appalled to see someone littering in our beautiful park.
It would appall my teacher if we didn't clean up our classroom after art class.
My parents were appalled when they found out I hadn't done my homework.
I feel appalled when I see kids being mean to each other on the playground.
The movie was supposed to be funny, but the scary part really appalled me.

meanings: Apparent" means something that is easy to notice or see, like when you can tell someone is happy just by looking at their smile.
examples: It was apparent that Sarah was excited about her birthday party when she couldn't stop smiling.
The teacher made it apparent that we needed to finish our homework before the weekend.
When the sun came out, it was apparent that spring had finally arrived.
During the game, it became apparent that Jake was the best player on our team.
It was apparent from the mess in the kitchen that my little brother had been baking cookies.

meanings: To clap your hands and cheer to show that you like what someone did, like after a performance or a game.
examples: After the school play, everyone stood up to applaud the actors for their amazing performance.
When my sister finished her drawing, I couldn't help but applaud her talent and hard work.
At the soccer game, the crowd began to applaud when our team scored the winning goal.
I will applaud my friend for helping me with my homework because she made it easier to understand.
When we finished cleaning up the park, the adults came to applaud us for our great teamwork.

meanings: To come closer to someone or something, like walking towards a friend to say hello.
examples: As I watched the soccer game, I could see my team approach the goal.
When I saw my dog in the park, I ran to approach him with a treat.
The teacher asked us to approach the project with creativity and teamwork.
As we hike up the hill, we will approach the beautiful view at the top.
I decided to approach my friend and ask if she wanted to play a game.

meanings: To say yes to something or to think it is good and okay.
examples: My teacher will approve my science project if I follow all the instructions carefully.
Mom will approve my choice of dessert if I finish my vegetables first.
The coach needs to approve our team uniforms before we can order them.
If my dad approves, I can invite my friends over for a movie night.
The librarian will approve my book recommendation if it is age-appropriate and interesting.

meanings: Being good at something or suited for a job or activity.
examples: Tom is apt at drawing, so his pictures always win prizes in art class.
Lisa is very apt at math and helps her classmates with their homework.
The dog is apt to fetch the ball quickly when we play in the yard.
During the game, Jake was apt at making the right moves to win.
My sister is apt to sing beautifully, and she always gets compliments.

meanings: To catch someone who has done something wrong and stop them from moving, like when a police officer takes someone to the station.
examples: The police officer had to arrest the thief who tried to take the old lady's purse.
During the game, the referee will arrest the play if someone breaks the rules.
When my dog runs away, I have to arrest him by calling his name to come back.
In the story, the hero needed to arrest the villain before he caused more trouble.
The teacher decided to arrest the noise in the classroom by asking everyone to be quiet.

meanings: Something that is made by people instead of being found in nature; for example, plastic toys are artificial because they are not real plants or animals.
examples: The flowers in my room are artificial, so they never need water or sunlight.
We used an artificial tree for our holiday decorations because it lasts a long time.
My mom bought artificial fruit for the kitchen, and it looks just like the real thing!
In science class, we learned that artificial intelligence helps computers think like people do.
I like my artificial pet robot because it can talk and dance just like a real pet!

meanings: To surprise someone so much that they can't believe it; it's like when you see something amazing and you say "Wow!
examples: My little brother can do a magic trick that will astonish everyone at the birthday party.
When I saw the giant rainbow in the sky, it truly astonished me with its beautiful colors.
The teacher's surprise announcement about our field trip astonished the whole class, and we cheered loudly.
I was astonished to find a tiny frog hopping in my backyard after the rain.
My dad's amazing skateboard tricks astonish all my friends when we watch him at the park.

meanings: To surprise someone very much, like when you see an amazing magic trick that you didn't expect.
examples: My teacher's magic trick astounded the whole class when she made a rabbit appear from a hat.
I was astound to find a hidden treasure map in my cereal box this morning.
Seeing the fireworks light up the sky on New Year's Eve always astounds me.
My dog learned a new trick, and it astounded my family when he rolled over on command.
The giant dinosaur skeleton at the museum astounded my friends and me with its size and details.

meanings: To attempt means to try to do something, even if it is hard. It's like when you practice a new skill, like riding a bike or solving a tricky puzzle.
examples: I will attempt to finish my homework before dinner so I can play outside.
My sister made an attempt to bake cookies, but they came out a little burnt.
During gym class, we will attempt to learn how to do a cartwheel.
I will attempt to climb the tall tree in my backyard this weekend.
My friends and I will attempt to build a fort out of blankets and pillows.

meanings: To go to a place or event, like a school class, a party, or a game, to be part of it.
examples: I will attend the school play with my family this Friday night.
My friends and I want to attend the soccer game this weekend.
We will attend the science fair to see all the cool projects.
I hope to attend the birthday party and eat cake with my friends.
My little brother is excited to attend his first music lesson tomorrow.

meanings: An audition is when someone tries out to see if they can be in a play, movie, or show. It's like a test to show how well they can act, sing, or dance!
examples: I practiced my lines for the school play before my big audition.
My sister is excited because she has an audition for the dance team this weekend.
We all cheered for our friend when she went to her audition for the lead role.
After school, I will help my friend prepare for her audition in the talent show.
My dog has a funny trick that I want to show during my audition for the pet show.

meanings: To ban something means to say that it is not allowed. For example, a school might ban running in the halls to keep everyone safe.
examples: The school decided to ban candy in the classroom to help us focus on learning.
My parents put a ban on video games until I finish my homework every night.
During the picnic, we had to ban running near the edge of the cliff for safety.
The teacher told us there is a ban on using our phones during class time.
Our coach placed a ban on eating junk food before the big soccer game this weekend.

meanings: To banish means to make someone leave a place as a punishment, like when a teacher tells a student to go to the principal's office for being naughty.
examples: The teacher decided to banish the noisy students to the hall for being disruptive during class.
In the game, the wizard can banish the monsters from the castle with a magic spell.
When the dog dug up the flowers, Mom said she would banish him to the backyard for a while.
During the team meeting, we agreed to banish any negative comments so everyone would feel happy.
If you break the rules at home, you might be banished from playing video games for a day.

meanings: A barrier is something that stops you from going through or getting past it, like a fence or a wall. It can also be something that makes it hard to do something, like a big problem you need to solve.
examples: The tall fence was a barrier that kept the dog from running into the street.
In soccer, a wall of players can act as a barrier to block the other team's kick.
A big rock was a barrier that stopped us from crossing the river during our hike.
When we played hide and seek, the bushes created a barrier between me and my hiding spot.
The snow made a barrier that blocked the path to our friend's house.

meanings: A benefit is something that helps you or makes things better. For example, eating healthy food is a benefit because it helps you grow strong and feel good.
examples: Eating fruits and vegetables has a big benefit for our health and helps us grow strong.
Helping my little brother with his homework can benefit both of us by making it easier to understand.
Playing outside every day has the benefit of keeping us active and making us feel happy.
When we work together on a project, the benefit is that we can share ideas and finish faster.
Reading books can benefit our imagination and help us learn new things about the world.

meanings: To blend means to mix different things together so they become one smooth mixture, like when you stir together paint colors or make a smoothie with fruits.
examples: When we make a smoothie, we blend fruits like bananas and strawberries together.
In art class, we can blend different colors of paint to create new shades.
I like to blend my favorite cereal with yogurt for a tasty breakfast.
My mom teaches me how to blend different spices to make our dinner delicious.
During the science project, we will blend sand and water to make cool shapes.

meanings: Bliss is a feeling of complete happiness and joy, like when you spend time with your best friend or enjoy your favorite ice cream.
examples: I felt bliss when I saw my best friend at the playground after a long time.
Reading my favorite book under a big tree brings me bliss every afternoon.
The puppy wagged its tail with bliss when I gave it a treat.
On a sunny day, flying a kite with my family fills me with bliss.
Winning the game with my team brought us all so much bliss at the party.

meanings: To blossom means when a flower opens up and shows its pretty petals, or when someone grows and gets better at something, like a skill or talent.
examples: In spring, the cherry trees begin to blossom, filling the park with beautiful pink flowers.
When we water the plants, we can see them blossom and grow tall in the garden.
My mom says that if I study hard, my knowledge will blossom like a flower.
After practicing every day, my soccer skills started to blossom, and I scored a goal!
The butterfly watched as the flowers began to blossom, creating a colorful scene in the meadow.

meanings: To boast means to talk about something great you did or something special you have, often to show off and make others notice how good it is.
examples: My brother loves to boast about his soccer skills after scoring a goal in the big game.
When I finished my science project, I couldn't help but boast about how cool it looked.
She likes to boast about her collection of rare stickers that she has saved for years.
At the school talent show, I heard some kids boast about their amazing dance moves.
Dad always boasts about the delicious cookies he bakes for our family gatherings.

meanings: To bore someone means to make them feel tired and uninterested, like when a story is too long or not exciting.
examples: The movie was so long that it started to bore me halfway through.
My little brother likes to play with toys that really bore me.
The math problems were too easy, and they began to bore the whole class.
I thought the book would be exciting, but it turned out to bore me instead.
We tried to play the game, but it was so slow that it began to bore us.

meanings: A bough is a big branch that grows out of a tree. It's one of the strong parts of the tree that helps hold up the leaves and fruit.
examples: The squirrel jumped from one bough to another in the big oak tree.
We hung a swing from a strong bough for the kids to play on.
During our picnic, we sat under a bough that gave us nice shade from the sun.
I watched a bird build a nest on the bough of our favorite tree.
The bough was so heavy with apples that it almost touched the ground.

meanings: The width of something from one side to the other, like how wide a table or a door is.
examples: The river has a great breadth, making it wide enough for boats to pass through easily.
In art class, we learned about the breadth of colors we can use to paint our pictures.
The width, or breadth, of the playground is perfect for running and playing games with friends.
My dad measured the breadth of the table to see if it would fit in the dining room.
The breadth of the garden allows us to grow many different kinds of flowers and vegetables.

meanings: To dig a hole or tunnel in the ground to make a cozy home, like how rabbits and other animals find shelter.
examples: The rabbit decided to burrow a cozy home under the big tree in our yard.
In the garden, the kids found a little hole where a mole must have burrowed.
When it gets cold outside, the fox will burrow into the ground to stay warm.
During our hike, we saw a squirrel burrow into the soft earth to hide its nuts.
My brother dug a deep hole in the sand at the beach, hoping to burrow to China!

meanings: To find out how much something is by doing math, like adding or subtracting numbers.
examples: I need to calculate how many stickers I have in my collection.
In math class, we will calculate the total cost of our school supplies.
Let's calculate how many pieces of candy we can share among our friends.
To bake cookies, we must calculate the right amount of ingredients we need.
I can calculate the distance from my house to the park using a map.

meanings: Having the skills or strength to do something well.
examples: My sister is capable of solving tricky math problems all by herself.
With practice, I know I am capable of riding my bike without training wheels.
Our dog is capable of learning new tricks if we teach him patiently.
During the science fair, I felt capable of explaining my project to everyone.
I believe I am capable of making a delicious sandwich for lunch today.

meanings: Capital is the city where the leaders of a country work and make important decisions.
examples: The capital of our country is where important leaders make big decisions.
In math class, we learned that capital means money that can help start a business.
My family visited the capital city to see the big buildings and museums.
We saved our allowance to buy a new game, using our capital wisely.
The capital letters at the start of sentences help show that they are important!

meanings: To touch someone softly and kindly, like when you hug a friend or stroke a pet to show you care.
examples: My mom gave me a gentle caress on my hair when I was feeling sad.
The puppy loved to receive a soft caress on its back while it wagged its tail.
After the game, my dad gave me a proud caress on my shoulder for doing my best.
I loved the way my sister would caress my arm when she wanted to comfort me.
The little girl would caress her doll softly while reading it a bedtime story.

meanings: To stop doing something or to make it come to an end, like when a fun game finishes and everyone goes home.
examples: When the bell rings, we must cease our talking and get ready for class.
The rain will cease soon, and we can go outside to play.
If you keep making noise, I will ask you to cease so I can concentrate.
During the movie, everyone had to cease eating popcorn to hear the sounds.
The teacher told us to cease our art projects when it was time to clean up.

meanings: A century is a time period that lasts for one hundred years, like how your great-grandparents lived in a different century than you do now.
examples: A century is a long time, like when dinosaurs roamed the Earth a hundred years ago.
My great-grandparents were born over a century ago, which is hard to imagine!
In a century, kids might play video games that we can't even dream of today.
I learned that a century is as long as five decades, which is really interesting!
The changes in technology over the last century have been amazing, like from phones to tablets.

meanings: A chamber is a special room used for important activities, like meetings or ceremonies, where people gather to talk or make decisions.
examples: The king held a meeting in the grand chamber of his castle.
In science class, we learned about the heart's chambers and how they pump blood.
The library has a quiet reading chamber where students can study alone.
We built a cozy chamber in the living room with blankets and pillows for our movie night.
The museum has a special chamber that shows how people lived in ancient times.

meanings: To cherish means to love something very much and take good care of it, like a favorite toy or a pet.
examples: I cherish the time I spend with my family during our weekend outings.
She cherishes her favorite stuffed animal and takes it everywhere she goes.
We should cherish our friendships because they make us happy and help us grow.
He cherishes the moments when he plays soccer with his teammates after school.
My grandma gave me a special necklace, and I will always cherish it.

meanings: A chord is when you play two or more music notes together at the same time to make a nice sound. It's like a team of notes working together to create a beautiful melody!
examples: The piano played a beautiful chord that made everyone smile during the school concert.
When I strummed my guitar, I made a happy chord that filled the room with music.
My music teacher taught us how to play a chord on the ukulele in class today.
We sang a song together, and our voices created a lovely chord that sounded so nice.
In music class, we learned that a chord can make a song sound full and exciting.

meanings: Climate is the usual weather in a place over many years, like how some places are hot and sunny while others are cold and snowy.
examples: The climate in our town is usually warm and sunny during the summer months.
Some animals, like penguins, live in cold climates where it snows a lot.
When we went to the beach, the warm climate made it perfect for swimming.
I learned that the climate can change from hot to cold in different seasons.
Scientists study the climate to understand how weather affects plants and animals.

meanings: To hold something very tightly in your hand, like when you grip a toy so it doesn't fall.
examples: I had to clutch my backpack tightly so it wouldn't fall off my shoulders.
During the game, I will clutch the basketball before making my shot.
She had to clutch her blanket when the thunderstorm started outside.
I watched my puppy clutch the toy in his mouth as he ran around the yard.
When I ride my bike down the hill, I always clutch the handlebars really tight.

meanings: To gently convince someone to do something they might not want to do, like asking a friend to play a game with you.
examples: I tried to coax my puppy to come inside by shaking his favorite toy.
Mom coaxed me to eat my vegetables by telling me they would help me grow strong.
My friends coaxed me to join their game by saying it would be so much fun!
Dad coaxed the bird to come closer by offering it some seeds from his hand.
I coaxed my little brother to share his crayons by promising he could use my stickers.

meanings: A column is a tall, straight line of words or numbers that goes up and down on a page, like in a list or a table. You can see columns in newspapers, where they help organize information.
examples: The teacher wrote our names in a column on the board for the group project.
In the newspaper, there is a column with fun facts about animals every week.
We arranged the books in a column on the shelf to keep the library neat.
During math class, we filled in a column with our scores from the last quiz.
My mom has a column in her planner to keep track of our family activities.

meanings: To communicate means to share your thoughts, feelings, or ideas with someone else, like talking, writing, or using gestures.
examples: We can communicate our ideas during group projects in class.
It’s important to communicate with your friends when you play games together.
My dog understands how to communicate when he wants to go outside.
We use our phones to communicate with family members who live far away.
During storytime, we can communicate our favorite parts of the book to each other.

meanings: To finish something so that it is all done or whole, like completing a puzzle when every piece is in its place.
examples: I need to complete my homework before I can play outside with my friends.
After I complete the puzzle, I will show it to my mom.
We work together to complete the science project for school.
Once I complete my chores, I can watch my favorite show.
My dad helped me complete the model airplane we started last week.

meanings: To concentrate means to pay close attention to something and not let other things distract you. It's like when you're really focused on your homework or playing a game and you block out all the noise...
examples: I need to concentrate on my homework so I can finish it before dinner.
During art class, I concentrate on coloring carefully to make my picture look nice.
It's hard to concentrate on my book when my little brother is making noise.
In soccer practice, I must concentrate on the coach's instructions to improve my skills.
When I concentrate while building my Lego set, I can create amazing things!

meanings: A concern is a feeling you get when you are worried about something or care a lot about it, like when a friend is sad or when you have a test coming up.
examples: I felt a lot of concern when my dog didn't eat his food.
My teacher showed concern for the students who were having trouble with math.
My mom has a concern about letting me ride my bike too far from home.
I expressed my concern when I saw my friend sitting alone at lunch.
The coach's concern for our safety made us feel better during the game.

meanings: To conclude means to make a choice or decision after thinking about something carefully. It's like when you finish reading a story and decide what you think about it.
examples: After discussing the project, the team will conclude who will present first.
I will conclude my book report after reading the last chapter tonight.
At the end of the game, we can conclude which team scored the most points.
She will conclude her speech by thanking everyone for listening.
We need to conclude our plans for the camping trip before the weekend.

meanings: To make sure something is true or correct, like when you check if your answer on a test is right.
examples: I need to confirm that my homework is finished before I turn it in.
My mom will confirm our trip to the zoo once she checks the weather.
Can you confirm if it’s your turn to play the game today?
I asked my teacher to confirm the date of the school field trip.
Before the party, I want to confirm who is bringing the snacks.

meanings: To confuse someone means to make them unsure or not able to understand something clearly, like when you mix up two similar words or ideas.
examples: The math homework was hard and it started to confuse me during class.
When I mixed up the colors, it made my painting confuse my friends at art time.
My little brother tried to tell a story, but it confused everyone because he forgot the ending.
Sometimes, different instructions can confuse us when we play new games with our friends.
The map was so tricky that it could confuse anyone trying to find the treasure!

meanings: To say something nice to someone because they did something great or won an award, like saying "Good job!" or "I'm proud of you!
examples: I want to congratulate my friend for winning the spelling bee at school.
When my sister scored a goal in soccer, I ran over to congratulate her.
We all congratulated our classmate for finishing the science project early.
Mom said we should congratulate Dad for getting a promotion at work.
After my brother finished his drawing, I congratulated him on his amazing art!

meanings: To think about something carefully before deciding what to do. For example, you might consider whether to play outside or do your homework first.
examples: I will consider which book to read for my book report this week.
Before choosing a game to play, I will consider what my friends like too.
My mom asked me to consider the best place for our picnic this weekend.
I need to consider my pet's feelings when I decide to get a new toy.
When planning a birthday party, I will consider what snacks everyone enjoys.

meanings: Considerable means something that is big or important enough to notice. For example, if you have a considerable amount of candy, it means you have a lot to share!
examples: I put in a considerable amount of effort to finish my school project on time.
The cake my mom baked had a considerable amount of chocolate frosting on top.
My dog made a considerable mess when he knocked over the trash can.
We collected a considerable number of leaves to make a big pile for jumping.
The basketball team made a considerable improvement this season and won many games.

meanings: To help someone feel better when they are sad or upset by being kind and supportive.
examples: I tried to console my friend when she was sad about losing her favorite toy.
After the game, I consoled my teammate who felt upset about missing the winning shot.
When my puppy got scared during the storm, I held him to console him.
I wrote a nice note to console my sister after she had a tough day at school.
My mom always knows how to console me when I feel nervous about a test.

meanings: Contempt is when you feel that someone or something is not important or doesn't deserve your respect. It's like feeling annoyed or looking down at someone for what they did.
examples: It is not nice to show contempt for a friend’s ideas during our group project.
When someone laughs at your mistakes, it can feel like they have contempt for you.
She felt contempt for the bully who always picked on her little brother.
The teacher explained that showing contempt for others can hurt their feelings.
In sports, we should always respect our opponents and not have contempt for them.

meanings: Feeling happy and satisfied with what you have or where you are.
examples: I felt content after finishing my favorite puzzle all by myself.
The puppy wagged its tail and looked content while resting in the sun.
After playing outside all day, I was content to sit and read a book.
The teacher was content when we all helped clean up the classroom together.
My mom smiled, feeling content when we had a nice dinner together as a family.

meanings: A contract is a special kind of promise between people that says they will do something for each other. It helps everyone remember what they agreed to do.
examples: My dad signed a contract to buy our new house last month.
At school, our teacher explained how a contract helps us follow the rules during group projects.
When I borrowed my friend's video game, we made a contract to return it in one week.
My sister and I made a contract to take care of our pet hamster together.
The soccer team had a contract that everyone would practice hard and support each other.

meanings: Contrast is when you see how two things are different from each other, like a bright red apple next to a dark green one.
examples: In contrast to my sister's loud music, I enjoy listening to quiet nature sounds.
The bright colors of the flowers stand in contrast to the dark green leaves around them.
In contrast to winter, summer is warm and sunny, perfect for playing outside.
My dog is big, while my cat is small, showing a fun contrast between them.
The two paintings have a contrast; one is bright and cheerful, while the other is dark and spooky.

meanings: To cower means to bend down or hide because you are scared of something. It's like when a dog gets low to the ground when it hears a loud noise.
examples: The dog began to cower when it heard the loud thunder outside.
When the teacher raised her voice, some students started to cower in their seats.
The little mouse would cower in its hole whenever the cat walked by.
During the scary movie, I saw my friend cower behind the couch.
The baby bird would cower under its mother’s wing when it felt afraid.

meanings: Crafty means being smart and using clever ideas to solve problems or get what you want, sometimes by tricking others in a playful way.
examples: My little brother is crafty; he always finds a way to sneak cookies before dinner.
During the game, Sarah was crafty and tricked everyone into thinking she was out.
The crafty fox in the story outsmarted the farmer to steal the chickens.
Emily made a crafty plan to surprise her mom on her birthday with a secret party.
When we played hide and seek, Jake was crafty and hid in the best spot ever!

meanings: To create means to make something new, like drawing a picture, building a sandcastle, or inventing a fun game.
examples: I want to create a colorful poster for our school project.
My sister and I will create a new game to play during recess.
We can create a special recipe for cookies using chocolate chips.
In art class, we will create beautiful paintings using bright colors.
I like to create stories about magical creatures in my notebook.

meanings: Crude means something that is rough, not finished, or made in a simple way, like a rock that hasn’t been shaped into a nice sculpture yet.
examples: The artist made a crude sketch of a dragon before painting it with bright colors.
Our teacher explained that crude oil is a natural resource we use to make fuel.
The kids built a crude fort out of blankets and chairs in the living room.
He wrote a crude poem for his friend’s birthday that made everyone giggle.
The chef used crude ingredients to make a simple but tasty soup for dinner.

meanings: Decay means when something slowly breaks down or falls apart, like when a piece of fruit gets soft and mushy after a while.
examples: The apple in the fruit bowl began to decay and turn brown after a week.
If you leave food out too long, it will start to decay and smell bad.
We learned in science class that leaves decay and help the soil become rich and healthy.
When you compost, you help food scraps decay into nutrient-rich soil for plants.
After a rainy day, the wooden fence started to decay because it got wet and didn't dry out.

meanings: Dejected means feeling sad or unhappy, especially when something doesn’t go the way you wanted it to, like losing a game or not getting a toy you hoped for.
examples: I felt dejected when I didn't make the soccer team this year.
After losing the game, the whole team looked dejected and quiet.
She was dejected when her favorite toy broke during playtime.
My brother seemed dejected after failing his math test.
Seeing my friend sad made me feel dejected, so I tried to cheer him up.

meanings: Deliberate means to think carefully about something before making a decision, like when you take your time to choose what game to play with your friends.
examples: We need to deliberate about which game to play at the birthday party.
Before making a decision, the teacher asked us to deliberate on the best project ideas.
The team took a moment to deliberate their strategy before the big soccer match.
My dad and I had a deliberate talk about what to do for our weekend adventure.
During our art class, we had to deliberate on the colors we wanted to use for our painting.

meanings: Depend means to need someone or something to help you or to be there for you, like when you depend on your parents to take care of you.
examples: I depend on my mom to help me with my homework every night.
In soccer, we depend on our teammates to work together and score goals.
My dog depends on me to feed him and take him for walks every day.
I depend on my teacher to explain things I don’t understand in class.
When I climb trees, I depend on my friends to help me get back down safely.

meanings: To take something away from someone so they can't have it anymore, like not letting a friend play with a toy.
examples: If you take my favorite toy, it will deprive me of my fun.
The rain can deprive us of playing outside during recess.
When you eat all the cookies, you deprive everyone else of a treat.
Missing school can deprive you of learning new things with your friends.
If we don’t share, we might deprive others of having a good time.

meanings: Depth is how far down something goes from the top to the bottom, like when you measure the water in a swimming pool from the surface to the bottom.
examples: The depth of the swimming pool is perfect for diving and playing games.
We measured the depth of the pond to see if we could catch fish.
The book was so interesting that I wanted to explore its depth of stories.
In science class, we learned about the depth of the ocean and its amazing creatures.
My dad dug a hole in the garden to check the depth of the soil for planting flowers.

meanings: To go down from a higher place to a lower place, like walking down stairs or flying down from the sky.
examples: The bird will descend from the tree to find food on the ground.
When we climbed the hill, we had to descend carefully to avoid slipping.
As the sun began to set, it slowly started to descend behind the mountains.
After the roller coaster ride, we could feel the car descend back to the ground.
My little brother loves to descend the slide at the playground really fast.

meanings: Desire is a strong feeling of wanting something really badly, like when you wish for a new toy or a special treat.
examples: I have a strong desire to learn how to ride my bike without training wheels.
Her desire to make new friends made her join the soccer team at school.
I felt a desire to bake cookies for my family after watching a cooking show.
His desire for adventure led us to explore the woods behind our house.
She has a desire to read every book in the library this summer.

meanings: To strongly dislike someone or something and think they are not good or important.
examples: I despise eating broccoli because it tastes so bitter and green.
Some kids despise playing tag when they always get caught and can't run fast.
I despise rainy days because I can't go outside to ride my bike.
My brother despises sharing his toys, even when I ask nicely.
She despises loud noises, especially when she is trying to read her book.

meanings: Causing a lot of damage or harm to something, like when a storm breaks trees or when someone breaks their toys.
examples: The storm was so destructive that it knocked down many trees in our neighborhood.
My little brother had a destructive habit of breaking his toys whenever he got mad.
The fire was destructive and burned down the old barn that we used to play in.
Some people think that littering is destructive because it harms the environment and animals.
When the sandcastle fell, it felt destructive to all the hard work we put into building it.

meanings: To detest something means to really, really dislike it, like when you taste a food that you think is yucky.
examples: I really detest broccoli because it tastes so bitter to me.
My brother detests cleaning his room; he would rather play video games instead.
She detests waking up early for school, especially on rainy days.
Some kids detest losing games, but I think it's fun to try again.
I detest watching scary movies because they make me feel really scared.

meanings: To grow or change into something better or more advanced, like when a seed turns into a plant or when you learn new skills.
examples: I want to develop my drawing skills so I can create amazing pictures.
When we water the plants, they start to develop into beautiful flowers.
In science class, we learned how to develop a simple experiment with our teacher.
As I practice playing soccer, I can develop better techniques to score goals.
My puppy will develop into a big dog if we take good care of him.

meanings: To disclose means to tell someone a secret or share information that was not known before.
examples: The teacher will disclose the winners of the art contest during the assembly.
My sister promised to disclose her secret recipe for cookies if I help her bake.
During story time, the librarian will disclose the name of the new book series we can read.
I will disclose my birthday party plans to my friends when we meet after school.
The coach will disclose the team lineup before the big game this weekend.

meanings: To feel sad or upset because something didn't go the way you hoped.
examples: I felt dismay when my favorite toy broke right before my birthday party.
It was a big dismay to see that it rained on the day of our picnic.
My teacher's dismay was clear when we didn't finish our homework on time.
I watched in dismay as my team lost the soccer game by just one point.
My mom showed dismay when she found out I forgot to feed the dog.

meanings: A dispute is when two or more people have different opinions and argue about something. It's like when you and a friend can't agree on which game to play.
examples: My brother and I had a dispute about who gets to play the video game first.
There was a dispute between my friends about which movie to watch on movie night.
The two teams had a dispute over the rules of the game during recess.
Mom and Dad had a small dispute about where to go for our family vacation.
During the art project, my classmates had a dispute about which colors to use.

meanings: Far away from something or someone; not near. For example, a distant star is very far away in the sky.
examples: The distant mountains looked beautiful against the blue sky.
My dog barked at a distant sound coming from the woods.
In the library, I found a book about distant planets in our galaxy.
We could see a distant rainbow after the rain stopped.
My grandma tells me stories about distant places she visited when she was young.

meanings: To distribute means to give out things to different people or places so that everyone gets some. For example, when you share candy with your friends, you are distributing the candy.
examples: The teacher will distribute the art supplies to each student before we start the project.
My dad likes to distribute snacks to everyone during movie night at home.
At the picnic, we will distribute sandwiches and drinks to all our friends.
The coach will distribute the team shirts before our first soccer game this weekend.
We learned how to distribute seeds evenly in the garden to help the plants grow better.

meanings: Something that is drab is plain and boring, with no bright colors or excitement. It feels lifeless, like a cloudy day with no sunshine.
examples: The sky looked drab and gray, so we decided to stay inside and play games.
Her drab shirt blended in with the boring school walls, making her look like a shadow.
The garden was drab in winter, but it will be colorful again when spring arrives.
He thought the drab toy was boring, so he painted it bright colors to make it fun.
Even though the book had a drab cover, the story inside was exciting and full of adventure.

meanings: Dreary means something that feels sad, dull, or boring, like a rainy day when you can't play outside. It makes you feel a little gloomy and not very happy.
examples: The sky was dreary, and it made me feel like staying inside all day.
After the rainy days, the garden looked dreary and needed some bright flowers.
Our field trip was canceled because of the dreary weather, so we stayed in class.
I felt dreary when I lost my favorite toy and couldn't find it anywhere.
The movie was so dreary that I wanted to cheer everyone up with a funny joke.

meanings: Feeling very sleepy and ready to fall asleep, like when you want to take a nap.
examples: After playing outside all day, I felt really drowsy and wanted to take a nap.
The warm sun made me drowsy while I was lying on the grass reading my book.
My puppy gets drowsy after a long walk and falls asleep on my lap.
During story time, I became drowsy and had to fight the urge to close my eyes.
On rainy days, I often feel drowsy and enjoy cuddling up in my blanket.

meanings: Dusk is the time of day when the sky starts to get dark and the sun goes down. It’s when the day is ending and night is about to begin.
examples: The sky turned beautiful colors of pink and orange at dusk when we finished our picnic.
As dusk fell, we watched the fireflies light up the backyard while we roasted marshmallows.
My dog loves to run around the yard at dusk when the sun is just disappearing.
We played outside until dusk, and then we went inside to have dinner together.
At dusk, the stars began to twinkle in the dark sky, and we made wishes on them.

meanings: Feeling very excited and ready to do something. For example, you might be eager to play a fun game or go on a trip!
examples: I was eager to see my friends at the birthday party this weekend.
My dog was eager to go for a walk when I grabbed his leash.
The class was eager to learn about space during our science lesson.
I felt eager to open my birthday presents as soon as I woke up.
After school, I was eager to start my new puzzle with my brother.

meanings: Ease means feeling relaxed and happy, like when you're playing your favorite game and everything feels just right. It’s when you don’t have any worries or stress.
examples: I felt a sense of ease when I finished my homework early.
The puppy lay on my lap, and I felt at ease while watching TV.
She played the piano with ease, making everyone clap for her.
My mom helped me with my project, so I could work with ease.
After a long day, I love to relax in my room with ease.

meanings: To eject means to push something out or make it leave. For example, when you press a button to make your video game cartridge pop out of the console.
examples: The teacher had to eject the paper from the printer because it got stuck.
When we played video games, I had to eject the disc to change the game.
The dog tried to eject the ball from under the couch with his nose.
During the science experiment, we had to eject the old batteries from the toy.
My brother forgot to eject the movie from the DVD player before we left the house.

meanings: An elder is a person who is older than others and is often looked up to for their knowledge and advice. They can be grandparents, teachers, or anyone who has lived longer and learned many things.
examples: My grandfather is an elder in our family, and he tells us amazing stories from his childhood.
In our school project, we learned about how elders in the community help the younger kids.
My sister is the elder sibling, so she often helps me with my homework.
During the camping trip, the elder scout taught us how to start a fire safely.
We listened carefully to the elder at the park who shared wisdom about taking care of nature.

meanings: To elevate means to lift something up higher, like when you raise your hand in class or when a bird flies up into the sky.
examples: The teacher used a platform to elevate her voice so everyone could hear her during the assembly.
I want to elevate my drawing skills by practicing every day after school.
When we stack the blocks higher, we can elevate our tower to reach the ceiling.
My dad helped me elevate my bike seat so I can ride it more comfortably.
During the game, we need to elevate our teamwork to win against the other team.

meanings: To eliminate means to take something away or make it disappear completely, like when you clean your room and throw away things you don’t need anymore.
examples: We need to eliminate the distractions in class so we can focus on our work.
When I cleaned my room, I decided to eliminate all the toys I no longer play with.
In soccer, we want to eliminate the other team’s chances of scoring a goal.
To stay healthy, it’s important to eliminate junk food and eat more fruits and vegetables.
The teacher asked us to eliminate any unnecessary words from our stories to make them clearer.

meanings: To embrace means to give someone a big hug because you care about them, or to accept an idea or change happily.
examples: I gave my little brother a big embrace when he was sad.
When I started a new school, I tried to embrace the change and make new friends.
My mom always tells me to embrace my unique talents and share them with others.
At the end of the game, we all came together to embrace our victory as a team.
When I found a new hobby, I decided to embrace it and practice every day.

meanings: To engage means to join in and take part in an activity or conversation, like when you raise your hand to answer a question in class or play a game with your friends.
examples: I always engage in my art projects after school because I love to draw and paint.
During gym class, we engage in different sports like soccer and basketball to stay active.
When we read a book, it helps us engage our imagination and think about the story.
My family likes to engage in board games on the weekends when we have free time together.
At the science fair, I will engage with other students to learn about their cool experiments.

meanings: To make sure something happens or is true. For example, you can ensure you have your homework ready before school.
examples: I will double-check my homework to ensure I have no mistakes.
Mom checks the oven to ensure the cookies are baking perfectly.
We need to water the plants every day to ensure they grow strong.
I set an alarm to ensure I wake up on time for school.
My teacher reminds us to study hard to ensure we do well on the test.

meanings: To keep someone happy and interested by doing something fun, like playing a game or telling a story.
examples: My dad tells funny jokes to entertain us during dinner.
The magician came to our school to entertain the whole class.
I like to draw pictures to entertain my little sister when she is bored.
Playing board games with friends always helps to entertain everyone on a rainy day.
My dog does silly tricks that never fail to entertain my family and me.

meanings: Entire means all of something without any parts missing. For example, if you eat an entire pizza, you eat the whole pizza, not just a slice!
examples: I read the entire book in one afternoon because I couldn't put it down.
The entire class went on a field trip to the science museum last week.
My mom baked an entire cake for my birthday party, and it was delicious!
We watched the entire movie together and laughed at all the funny parts.
The entire garden is filled with colorful flowers that attract buzzing bees.

meanings: A door or opening that lets you go into a place, like a house or a building. It's where you start when you want to get inside.
examples: We found a secret entrance to the treehouse in our backyard.
The entrance to the school was decorated with colorful balloons for the party.
My dog ran to the entrance of the house when he heard me call.
The entrance to the playground was crowded with happy kids playing together.
During the hike, we discovered a hidden entrance to a cave in the mountains.

meanings: Entry means the act of going into a place, like when you walk through a door to get inside a room or building.
examples: When I opened the door, I saw a big entry with colorful decorations.
The entry to the playground has a slide and swings waiting for us to play.
I wrote my name in the entry of my journal before starting my story.
At the museum, the entry was filled with interesting pictures and statues.
We made a special entry in our scrapbook to remember our fun trip to the zoo.

meanings: To equip means to give someone the tools or things they need to do a job or activity. For example, when you get a backpack with school supplies, you are equipped for school.
examples: The school will equip us with new books for our reading class this year.
Before the camping trip, my dad will equip us with tents and sleeping bags.
Our soccer coach will equip each player with a uniform and shin guards.
I will equip my robot toy with batteries so it can move and talk.
To help my puppy learn, I will equip him with a collar and a leash.

meanings: To escort someone means to go with them to keep them safe or help them. It's like when a friend walks you to the playground to make sure you get there safely.
examples: The teacher asked a student to escort the new kid to the playground.
My dad will escort me to the bus stop after school today.
During the field trip, a guide will escort us through the museum.
I will escort my little sister while she rides her bike in the park.
In the game, a knight's job is to escort the princess safely home.

meanings: Very important and needed for something to work or to be okay. For example, food and water are essential for staying healthy.
examples: Water is essential for all living things, including plants, animals, and people.
It is essential to wear a helmet when riding a bike to keep your head safe.
Good friends are essential because they make us feel happy and supported.
Studying is essential if you want to do well on your tests at school.
Having a good breakfast is essential to give you energy for the day ahead.

meanings: To evaporate means to turn from a liquid, like water, into a gas or vapor, usually when it gets warm, like when puddles dry up on a sunny day.
examples: When the sun shines on the puddle, the water will slowly evaporate into the air.
If you leave a glass of juice out, it will evaporate and leave behind a sticky mess.
After the rain, the warm breeze will help the water on the grass evaporate quickly.
When I boil water for pasta, I watch the steam as it makes the water evaporate.
In science class, we learned that heat can make ice evaporate and turn into water vapor.

meanings: Something that happens later, after a while or after some other things have happened.
examples: After practicing every day, I hope to see my eventual improvement in playing the piano.
We planted seeds in the garden, and we are excited for the eventual flowers to bloom.
If we keep studying hard, our eventual success on the test will make us very proud.
My dog learned to fetch the ball, and his eventual performance in the park impressed everyone.
We worked together on the project, and our eventual teamwork helped us get a good grade.

meanings: To go beyond what is allowed or expected, like scoring more points in a game than you thought you would.
examples: My test score exceeded my expectations, and I was so happy with my hard work.
The team exceeded their goal and won the championship game by five points.
When I baked cookies, the smell exceeded my hopes, and they tasted amazing!
My little brother can exceed his bedtime if he finishes all his homework early.
The garden plants exceeded their growth this summer and reached the top of the fence.

meanings: Exceptional means something or someone is really special or much better than most; like when you do an amazing job in a school project.
examples: My teacher said my project on space was exceptional and really impressed everyone in class.
The exceptional team won the soccer tournament because they worked well together and practiced hard.
I found an exceptional book at the library that had the most amazing adventure story.
My dog is exceptional at catching the frisbee; he never misses a throw!
We had an exceptional picnic in the park with delicious food and fun games to play.

meanings: To shout or say something suddenly because you are surprised or feel really strong emotions, like when you see a puppy and shout, "Look at that cute dog!
examples: "Wow!" she exclaimed when she saw the huge ice cream sundae in front of her.
He couldn't help but exclaim in joy when he won the game with his last score.
When the puppy did a funny trick, we all exclaimed in surprise and laughter.
"Look at that rainbow!" my sister exclaimed, pointing at the colorful sky after the rain.
I exclaimed with excitement when I opened my birthday present and saw the new robot toy inside.

meanings: To show something that was hidden or not seen before, like revealing a surprise or opening a box to see what’s inside.
examples: The teacher will expose the secret behind how plants grow during our science lesson.
When we took the blanket off the table, it exposed the beautiful tablecloth underneath.
The flashlight helped us expose the treasure hidden in the dark corner of the room.
In the game, we had to expose the hidden clues to find the missing treasure map.
The sun will expose all the colors of the rainbow after the rain stops.

meanings: Exquisite means something that is very beautiful and special, like a pretty flower or a lovely piece of art that makes you feel happy when you see it.
examples: The artist painted an exquisite picture of a rainbow that everyone admired.
My grandma made an exquisite cake decorated with flowers for my birthday party.
The butterfly landed on a flower, showing its exquisite colors in the sunlight.
I found an exquisite seashell on the beach that sparkled in the sand.
Her dress was exquisite, with tiny beads that shimmered like stars at night.

meanings: External means something that is on the outside or surface of something else, like the outside of a house or the skin on your body.
examples: The external part of the tree trunk is rough, while the inside is soft and smooth.
We painted the external walls of our playhouse bright colors to make it look cheerful.
The external decorations on my birthday cake were colorful sprinkles and shiny candles.
When we went hiking, we saw many external parts of plants, like leaves and flowers.
My mom said the external features of the house, like the roof and windows, need to be fixed.

meanings: To extinguish means to put out a fire or light so that it stops burning. For example, you can extinguish a candle by blowing it out.
examples: The firefighters worked hard to extinguish the flames in the tall building.
I used a blanket to extinguish the small fire in the fireplace safely.
After the campfire, we made sure to extinguish the ashes before leaving the site.
My dad taught me how to extinguish the candle before we go to bed.
We need to extinguish the lanterns when we finish our outdoor games at night.

meanings: Familiar means something you know well or see often, like your favorite toy or a close friend.
examples: The dog in the park looked familiar because I had seen it before.
When I opened the book, the story felt familiar and made me smile.
I felt familiar with the game because my brother taught me how to play it.
The smell of cookies baking in the oven was familiar and made me feel at home.
My teacher's voice was familiar because she taught my class last year, too.

meanings: Very, very hungry; it feels like you need food right away!
examples: After playing soccer for two hours, we were all famished and ready for lunch.
I woke up so famished that I could hear my stomach growling for breakfast.
When we got home from the long hike, we were famished and ate a big dinner.
My little brother was famished after school, so he quickly grabbed a snack.
The campers were famished by the time dinner was ready, and they couldn't wait to eat.

meanings: A fanatic is a person who is really, really excited about something, like a sport or a hobby, and sometimes they care about it more than anything else.
examples: My brother is a soccer fanatic who watches every game on TV.
She is a book fanatic and reads a new story every night before bed.
Tom is such a video game fanatic that he plays for hours after school.
My dad is a car fanatic and loves to talk about different kinds of engines.
At the science fair, Mia was a fanatic about showing her experiment to everyone.

meanings: Fare is the money you pay to ride a bus, train, or taxi.
examples: The bus fare to school is two dollars each way.
I saved my allowance to pay the fare for the train ride.
When we take the subway, I always check how much the fare costs.
My dad said the fare for the ferry to the island is really fun!
We need to find enough change for the fare to get home after the game.

meanings: A feud is a long and angry disagreement between two people or groups, like when two friends stop talking to each other because of a big argument.
examples: The two families in the neighborhood had a feud over whose dog barked the loudest.
In the game, the players started a feud when they argued about the rules.
My brother and I had a silly feud about who gets the last piece of pizza.
The two friends ended their feud and decided to work together on the school project.
The feud between the rival sports teams made the game more exciting for everyone watching.

meanings: Able to bend or stretch easily without breaking, like a rubber band. It can also mean being open to new ideas or changes, like when you can change your plans and still have fun.
examples: The yoga teacher showed us how to be flexible like a tree swaying in the wind.
My rubber band is very flexible, so I can stretch it into different shapes.
In gym class, we practiced flexible moves to help us do better in gymnastics.
My mom is flexible with my bedtime on weekends when I finish my homework early.
The artist used a flexible brush to create beautiful swirls on the canvas.

meanings: Foliage is all the leaves on a plant or tree, especially when there are many of them together. It makes the plant look green and full!
examples: The colorful foliage in the park made our nature walk feel like a magical adventure.
During the fall, the trees lose their green foliage and show beautiful red and orange leaves.
We found a cozy spot under the thick foliage to have our picnic and enjoy the sunshine.
The garden was filled with lush foliage, making it a perfect hiding place for our game of hide and seek.
As we drove through the mountains, I loved looking at the dense foliage covering the hills.

meanings: To forbid means to tell someone they cannot do something. For example, a parent might forbid a child from eating too much candy.
examples: My parents forbid me from eating too many sweets before dinner.
The teacher will forbid students from using phones during class time.
The sign in the park forbids people from picking the flowers.
My coach will forbid us from playing soccer if it rains too hard.
My sister's friend was forbidden to come over because she was sick.

meanings: A forecast is a way of telling what the weather will be like in the future, like if it will be sunny, rainy, or snowy.
examples: The weather forecast says it will rain tomorrow, so we need to bring our umbrellas.
In science class, we learned how to forecast the weather using clouds and temperatures.
My dad checks the weather forecast every morning to decide if we can go to the park.
The forecast predicts sunny skies for the weekend, which is perfect for our picnic!
Our teacher asked us to forecast what the temperature will be next week based on the patterns we see.

meanings: The word "foremost" means being the most important or the first in line. For example, if you are the foremost player on your team, it means you are the best or the one everyone looks up to.
examples: My teacher said that learning math is foremost for doing well in school.
When we play soccer, teamwork is foremost for winning the game.
My dog is foremost in my heart because he always makes me happy.
In our family, kindness is the foremost rule we follow every day.
Reading books is foremost on my list of favorite hobbies after school.

meanings: Feeling very sad and alone, like when you lose your favorite toy or your friends can't play with you.
examples: The forlorn puppy sat by the door, waiting for its owner to come home.
After losing the game, Jake felt forlorn because he really wanted to win.
When her friends left for the field trip without her, Mia felt very forlorn and lonely.
The forlorn toy sat on the shelf, wishing someone would play with it again.
As the last leaf fell from the tree, it looked forlorn in the cold wind.

meanings: To forsake means to leave someone or something behind and not take care of them anymore, like when a friend stops playing with you and doesn't want to be friends anymore.
examples: I decided not to forsake my old stuffed animal, even though I got a new one.
When my friend moved away, I felt sad but I didn’t forsake our friendship.
It’s not nice to forsake your teammates when you’re playing a game together.
I promised to never forsake my puppy, even when he gets messy.
Sometimes, people forsake their favorite hobbies when they get busy with school.

meanings: A fortress is a strong building where people can stay safe from danger or attacks. It often has high walls and can protect those inside.
examples: The castle in the story was a strong fortress that protected the king and his treasure.
During our game, we built a pillow fortress to keep our toys safe from the imaginary dragons.
In art class, we painted a picture of a fortress surrounded by trees and a sparkling river.
The soldiers trained hard to defend their fortress from the enemy in the big video game.
When we went camping, we made a fort with branches that felt like a secret fortress in the woods.

meanings: Feeling very lucky or having good things happen to you. For example, if you find a dollar on the ground, you might feel fortunate!
examples: I felt fortunate to get a new bike for my birthday.
My family is fortunate because we have a warm home to live in.
She was fortunate to find a four-leaf clover in the garden.
We are fortunate to have a great teacher who makes learning fun.
He felt fortunate when he won the game and got a prize.

meanings: A founder is a person who starts something new, like a company or a club, and helps make it grow. They are like the first builder of a big project!
examples: The founder of our school started it to help kids learn and make friends.
My dad is the founder of a new game that we all love to play together.
In art class, we learned about the founder of a famous painting and his techniques.
The founder of our club created it to encourage kids to explore nature and have fun.
When I grow up, I want to be the founder of my own animal rescue organization.

meanings: Fragile means something that can break easily, like a glass toy or a thin piece of paper. You need to be careful with fragile things so they don’t get damaged.
examples: The glass vase on the table is very fragile, so we need to be careful not to bump it.
My little sister dropped her fragile doll, and now its arm is broken.
When we went hiking, we saw a fragile flower that could easily be crushed by our feet.
The fragile wings of the butterfly sparkled in the sunlight as it flew by.
I wrapped my fragile art project in bubble wrap to keep it safe on the way to school.

meanings: Frequent means something that happens a lot or many times, like seeing your friends at school every day.
examples: I frequent the library after school to read new books.
My dog wants to go for frequent walks in the park.
We have frequent game nights with our family every Saturday.
My teacher gives us frequent reminders about our homework due dates.
I visit my grandma's house on frequent weekends to help her in the garden.

meanings: Fringe is a decoration made of thin threads or strips that hang down from the edge of something, like a curtain or a blanket. It can also mean something that is not very popular or is on the outside o...
examples: The fringe of the blanket kept my toes warm on the chilly night.
During arts and crafts, I added a fringe of colorful paper to my project.
The fringe of the forest is where many animals like to play and hide.
At the party, we decorated the tables with a fringe of shiny ribbons.
My favorite shirt has a fringe at the bottom that makes it look cool.

meanings: A frontier is the edge of a place where people live, and beyond it is wild land that hasn’t been explored yet. It’s like the border between your neighborhood and a big, unknown forest.
examples: The explorers traveled to the frontier to discover new lands and meet interesting animals.
In science class, we learned about the frontier of space and the planets beyond Earth.
My grandpa told me stories about the frontier when people were settling in the wild West.
When we go hiking in the forest, we always feel like we're at the frontier of nature.
The video game takes you to the frontier of a magical world full of adventures.

meanings: Furious means being very, very angry, like when something really upsetting happens and you can feel the heat in your face.
examples: My mom was furious when I forgot to clean my room again.
Jake was furious after losing the game because he practiced so hard.
When my sister took my favorite toy without asking, I felt furious.
The teacher was furious when she found out someone was being mean to a classmate.
I was furious when my ice cream fell on the ground right after I bought it.

meanings: A gash is a big, deep cut on your skin that can hurt a lot. It might bleed and needs to be taken care of to help it heal.
examples: I slipped on the playground and got a gash on my knee.
The dog accidentally scratched my arm, leaving a small gash.
When I was climbing a tree, I got a gash on my hand from a branch.
After the bike ride, I noticed a gash on my leg from the rough path.
My brother fell while running and ended up with a gash on his forehead.

meanings: A gesture is a movement you make with your hands or body to show how you feel or to help explain something, like waving hello or giving a thumbs up.
examples: When I waved goodbye to my friend, it was a kind gesture.
The coach gave a thumbs-up gesture to show we were doing great.
My mom made a heart shape with her hands as a sweet gesture.
I used a big smile as a gesture to show I was happy.
During the game, my teammate made a gesture to pass the ball to me.

meanings: A glimpse is a quick look at something that doesn't last very long, like when you see a bird fly by for just a second.
examples: I caught a glimpse of a rainbow after the rain stopped.
When I looked out the window, I saw a glimpse of my dog chasing a squirrel.
During the school play, I got a glimpse of my mom smiling in the audience.
As I walked through the zoo, I had a quick glimpse of the lions sleeping.
My little sister had a glimpse of her birthday cake before the party started.

meanings: Grace is when someone moves in a smooth and beautiful way, like a dancer or a person being kind and polite to others.
examples: The ballerina danced with such grace that everyone in the audience clapped loudly.
My dog runs with grace when he chases the squirrel in the yard.
The way my sister paints shows her grace and talent for art.
During the soccer game, the player moved with grace as he dribbled the ball past his friends.
The butterfly flew through the garden with grace, making it look like a magical place.

meanings: A grove is a small group of trees that grow close together, like a tiny forest where you can play hide and seek.
examples: We found a cozy grove of trees to have our picnic in the park.
The birds built their nests in the grove behind our house.
In the grove, we saw squirrels playing and chasing each other.
During our nature walk, we discovered a beautiful grove filled with flowers.
My sister and I like to play hide and seek in the small grove near our school.

meanings: Hail" means to shout out to someone to say hello or get their attention, like when you wave and say 'hi' to a friend across the playground.
examples: I saw my friend at the park, so I decided to hail him from across the field.
When I spotted my dad in the crowd, I waved to hail him over to me.
At the game, I tried to hail the coach to ask him about my position.
When we arrived at the zoo, I began to hail my classmates so they wouldn’t get lost.
I always hail my grandma when she visits, because I’m excited to see her!

meanings: A hamlet is a very small village where people live, usually with just a few houses and no big stores or schools. It's a quiet place, like a tiny neighborhood in the countryside.
examples: I visited a small hamlet where everyone knows each other and waves hello.
My grandma lives in a hamlet surrounded by fields and friendly animals.
We saw a beautiful sunset while walking through the quiet hamlet after dinner.
In the hamlet, there is a tiny store that sells ice cream and toys.
The children in the hamlet play games in the grassy fields every afternoon.

meanings: Hearty means showing a lot of warmth and kindness, like when you give a big, friendly hug or cheer loudly for your friend.
examples: My grandma gave me a hearty hug when I came to visit her.
The class gave a hearty cheer when our team won the game.
We had a hearty laugh while telling funny stories around the campfire.
My puppy wagged his tail with hearty excitement when I came home.
The teacher gave us a hearty welcome on the first day of school.

meanings: A helm is the part of a ship where the captain steers and controls the boat. It’s like the steering wheel in a car, helping to guide where the ship goes.
examples: In the school play, Mia took the helm and helped everyone remember their lines.
During our camping trip, Dad wore a helmet to protect his head while riding his bike at the helm of the group.
When we play soccer, I like to take the helm and decide which way to run with the ball.
At the birthday party, Ava was at the helm, making sure everyone got a piece of cake.
In our class project, I took the helm and organized all the ideas we wanted to share.

meanings: To hibernate means to sleep for a long time during the winter when it's cold, like how bears take a long nap until spring comes.
examples: Bears hibernate in caves during the winter to stay warm and safe from the cold.
When it gets too chilly outside, some animals choose to hibernate until spring.
My pet turtle likes to hibernate in its shell when it feels sleepy and cold.
In winter, many animals hibernate so they can save energy until food is easier to find.
We learned that frogs can hibernate under mud when the weather gets really cold.

meanings: A host is a person who invites others to their home or event and makes sure everyone feels welcome and happy.
examples: Our teacher will host a fun science experiment in class next week.
My mom decided to host a birthday party for me at our house.
The school will host a talent show where students can show their skills.
My friend is going to host a sleepover this weekend with games and movies.
The library will host storytime for kids every Saturday morning.

meanings: Hue is a word that means a specific color, like red, blue, or green. Think of it as the different shades you see in a rainbow!
examples: The sunset painted the sky with a beautiful hue of orange and pink.
My favorite color has always been the bright blue hue of the ocean.
In art class, we mixed colors to create a new hue for our painting.
The flowers in the garden bloom in every hue you can imagine.
My sister chose a soft purple hue for her bedroom walls.

meanings: Being humble means not thinking you are better than others and being okay with being yourself. It’s like when someone wins a game but still cheers for their friends.
examples: Even though she won the race, Maria was humble and thanked her friends for cheering her on.
After scoring the most points in the game, Jake remained humble and encouraged his teammates.
My dad always teaches me to be humble, even when I do something really great.
When I helped my neighbor, she was humble and said she appreciated my kindness.
The humble puppy wagged his tail happily, even though he was the smallest in the litter.

meanings: To make someone feel really bad about themselves or to make them feel embarrassed in front of others.
examples: I felt humiliated when I tripped and fell during the school play in front of everyone.
It can humiliate a friend if you tease them about their mistakes during a game.
When I forgot my lines, I was worried it would humiliate me in front of my classmates.
It's not nice to humiliate someone by laughing at them when they make a mistake.
My brother tried to humiliate me by showing my silly dance moves to everyone at the party.
